entry.title: Concern about "Inscriptions"
entry.summary: The discussion focuses on the growth potential and storage limitations of the blockchain. It is argued that while the rate of growth may be high, the storage capacity is sufficient. In a worst-case scenario, assuming maximum block size and block time, the blockchain would grow by 210.24GB per year. However, with the decreasing cost of hardware, it is estimated that a 5TB hard drive costing less than $150 can last for 21 years before running out of space. Efforts to optimize storage by nodes, such as the use of utreexo, are also mentioned.Another topic discussed is unconfirmed transactions and their impact on the network. The need to price space in the UTXO set is proposed as a way to determine whether certain transactions are spam or not. It is suggested that pricing UTXOs based on resource costs could potentially reduce the usage of inscriptions. However, it is acknowledged that implementing such a mechanism may offend some Bitcoin users.During the discussion, the difficulty of preventing spam transactions known as "inscriptions" from reaching miners and being included in blocks is addressed. It is noted that even if a majority of the network were to upgrade their relay policy to prevent propagation of inscriptions, users could still send non-standard transactions directly to miners or change the script used to embed an inscription. The discussion highlights the challenges of preventing inscriptions and proposes economic means as the best solution. Appeals to Satoshi Nakamoto are deemed unconvincing.Issues with using pre-segwit nodes and the need for a comprehensive solution to address the growing UTXO set and initial blockchain download time are also discussed. It is suggested that simply blocking inscriptions in the mempool would not be a sufficient solution and could lead to a never-ending chase of constantly blocking new methods used by spammers.Inscriptions are being introduced in the Bitcoin community, even on chains without Taproot or Segwit. These inscriptions are primarily used to sell NFTs or Tokens, concepts that have been rejected by the community. However, miners and nodes do not enforce these additional rules, leading to valid Bitcoin transactions becoming invalid Ordinals transactions. This raises concerns about more serious underlying issues such as initial blockchain download (IBD) time and UTXO size.The introduction of inscriptions reflects the acceptance of sidechains in a more centralized form, despite initial rejection by the community. Soft-forks are unstoppable concepts, and inscription creators have implemented a version that is not enforced. This highlights the limited control over the rules and regulations surrounding inscriptions.For more information on the discussion, you can refer to the original email thread on the bitcoin-dev mailing list provided in the context.
